reviews.review_msg: This guy is full of himself.
Well done David, wonderful job- make your teachers proud. :)

When releasing course assignments, it could be greatly beneficial if David were to discuss some of his current research to encourage student researchers and to draw parallels to coursework, especially if he were to focus on his personal research process and writing techniques as an example breakdown of a professional researcher's writing system.

David possesses an innate ability to explain complex concepts with patience and clarity, ensuring that every student feels supported and understood while learning his subject matter. No question felt too small or insignificant; he creates a safe and nurturing environment where students feel comfortable expressing themselves and seeking guidance.

David's job necessitates working with hundreds of people every term, many of whom may go through different life phases during the course- including major life events, illnesses, and everyday ups and downs alongside more regular academic concerns. He is inspiring in his willingness to keep attempting the caring and supporting functions of this role.

Every lecture I had the privilege to attend was illuminating, but David's last HSCI 206 lecture in week 12 was my favourite memory at SFU and the most impressive lecture I have witnessed. To discuss it would almost be to ruin it, but I fear that there could not be enough praise or encouragement to continue orating. May your abilities be protected.

David is very conscientious and hardworking- I felt so respected by how carefully he managed time during lectures so as to teach us as much of the syllabus as possible. Nevertheless, I feel passionate about fifteen minutes of celebration at the end of the very last lecture so that we can all make some fun memories with him and reward ourselves. :)

I would love to see professors use polls to engage students and gather feedback during the course, especially regarding the difficulty of material each week. This could prompt students to create study groups or share revision notes. As courses can feel impersonal, perhaps we could also share something small, like a song? (K'lma - Warda Ala Warda)

Difficult course, concepts are not very well explained in lectures. Slides are difficult to understand for those with no economics background. Midterm assignments are hard and based on abstract topics.

Really enjoyable lectures. I was excited to study this subject and really value David's consistent efforts during lecture and outside of class. David's presentations made health economics one of my favourite subjects! I hope to keep adding to my knowledge base with further study and by reading related research.

David wasn't a bad professor, he seems nice and cares for his students. Lectures were pretty boring after the first hour and was hard to pay attention. Midterms, quizzes, and final I found fair but you need to go to lecture because the slides don't make sense without it.
Loved it :)

David might be a good person but I did not enjoy the course. The final was A LOT of writing (everything was essay). His teaching was all over the place; lectures were long and dull and did not make sense. I learned a lot from research papers I read for assignments (also essays). I personally won't take him again, it was too much emotional damage.

David's quizzes and midterms were fair and related to the lecture content. Be ready to attend all lectures and pay attention to what he says to do well in this class. His sense of humour made lectures enjoyable. Textbook will enhance your understanding of concepts but it's not necessary to read all the chapters. One of my favourite profs!

the previous reviews r so weird so lemme put a real n honest one!!! he is okay lecturer he gets kinda boring sometimes, the slides r kinda empty n make no sense if u dont go to class, he gives take home midterms but in person quizzes. u can get by the class without using reading the textbook or required readings too so overall hes pretty decent

You need to attend lectures if you want to succeed in the course but don't worry because his lectures are actually engaging. He doesn't just read off the slides and actually takes his time explaining concepts Instead of rushing through them. Only downfall is that he's a Stoke City fan :)

Two Quizzes, Two Take-home midterms and a Final. Not too bad

Gave few opportunities for students to be successful. Based our entire grade on 4 assessments & made the final extremely difficult. Expected us to write a 1.5hr essay with references, but no notes or articles were allowed in with us, plus an extra 3 short essay questions & a quiz. Didn't explain concepts well or care about student success.

I'm really not sure what the people rating him are on about. He is a decent prof. However, his lecture material can be quite dry and the essay topics on the midterms or phrasing on quizzes can be confusing sometimes. Also, if you skip class, the slides are completely useless.

I hope David publishes a paper on the health-related benefits of the CleanBC 2030 mandate for zero-emission light duty vehicle sales (90% by 2030; 100% by 2035). I was grateful to read the 2018 economic analysis he co-authored calculating health related benefits of bicycle infrastructure investment using the WHO's Health Economic Assessment Tool.

It is very important to contact David if you are concerned about a course matter. I was worried to at first but relaxed as I understood that he is a very experienced professor and has many more love and care miles on his love and care meter than I do. I also recommend excitedly staying in real time with notes, readings and components (no delays).

I taught HS Bio and was defeated by how repeatedly explaining content in a memorable way felt more like acting than teaching. As I taught and acted my content more than 5 times I felt the strangest guilt- acting felt like lying. Given how many times David has taught 206, he is a true master and lectures without feeling/revealing that awkward guilt!

I hope David retires peacefully and knows that he is respected for being able to attain financial stability for himself and his family, ensuring their healthier futures. I wasn't allowed to make decisions regarding the allocation of family resources and was happy to learn economic concepts from David; I suggest more in-class practical assignments.

Forgive me, I was not punctual when I submit and my writing standard was not even close to professor David's research calibre. I love to read his research as it comes out and despite environmental concerns, I wish we had the old fashioned enjoyment of hard-bound journals to encourage us.

I am so grateful for David who allowed me to make a Monday 9am appointment to ensure I started my week productively and felt calm.

I hope that David and all his future students stay informed, take good rest, feel supported, are open to change, know that they are strong to keep going despite setbacks, and believe that everything will be okay.

This course is graded on a curve. Unfortunately, you, like me, may overestimate your grade. 

Please read and apply this knowledge to your SFU academics:
Personal contact, individuation, and the better-than-average effect. (Alicke, M. D et al.) 
Flawed Self-Assessment Implications for Health, Education, and the Workplace (David Dunning et al.)

I frequently wish I could hear David's thoughts and perspective as he has believes that everything can be explained by economics; it fascinates me to try to think like him in my everyday life. My mind primarily understands the world through the sciences and mathematics and I would have loved to further discuss human behaviour through both lenses.

I wish David could experience the joy of teaching all of his students until they mastered his content material to an A standard. I believe that if he was part of a safe, respectful community of adults he would be allowed the joy of working towards this goal; this high teaching standard is integral to the health of everyone in the community.

I am very grateful for lectures when David took the time to share some of the depth of his knowledge regarding pain and pain management. They are such sensitive, difficult topics to discuss and David does it with great compassion and courage, introducing preference-based measures of quality of life and wellbeing used in health economic evaluation.

David has conscientiously taught and researched with students from various backgrounds with different perspectives for 10+ years in a trimester system. This extensive experience and his high-priority research in health state description and valuation makes him especially capable of handling sensitive situations with patience and kindness.

David breaks down difficult information and feeds it to you like you are a baby bird. Please don't fear this subject, just enjoy taking notes, write your papers in advance and follow the rubric. Respectfully ask questions and for any help during office hour and discuss his research (what he really loves). Contribute to classes and sit at the front.

David is a respected professor and I highly reccommend taking a course. He was a brilliant, engaging lecturer who is a gymnast-  lecturing (a difficult skill) is done so artfully that people don't comprehend how difficult it is. David responds to emails promptly but I recc. office hours- he is very empathetic and is right there. Be ready to write!

His lecture slides won't be useful if you skipped the class so it's better to learn from the readings. Either than that if you go to the class and just listen and take a few notes on the slides he explains it's not that hard to understand. The marking is fair but can be a bit hard. Just go to the class and you'll do fine.
One of the worst profs I've ever had!!!!  Useless lecture slides!! And he is awful at explaining them!!!!!

This course was not easy, especially for students without any economic background. Whitehurst's slides were not as useful, he does not upload them until AFTER the lecture is complete, and there were 5 papers in this course. I had to heavily rely on the textbook because I found that he didn't explain a lot of the concepts well in the lecture.

The course content was pretty hard, but David himself was an amazing professor. He definitely knew his content and was very helpful throughout the semester. You could ask him for help at any time, and he would respond really quickly. The class was very long 3 hours, but there were a couple 15 min breaks in between. The TA marks hard but was fair.

One of the worst professors I had. His slides are useless as it is really empty and not much information is on the slides. Super long and boring lecture(3-hour lecture per week). Prepare to read thousands of different materials he prepared. Good luck for those who have no economic concept background as the course required lots of economic concepts.

Dr. Whitehurst is a great professor, and his best feature is that he is accessible outside class, or even during the breaks. The course content is pretty heavy, but I would say if you dont miss classes, study properly, and reach out to him, you can end up with a very good mark. The pro tip is to ask questions and clarify your doubts.

Class was very straightforward and so were assignments, course was taught in a good way as well. I really recommend Professor. Whitehurst and taking hsci 206! One of my favourite classes so far, it made me realize i have a passion for health economics

David is very knowledgeable at what he studies, however, his assignments are very brief and the marking can be a bit tough. He is a nice person but sometimes I get the feeling that he is annoyed when students ask questions that he already covered in the syllabus or previous emails.
